title-group.article-title: Calculation of Random Vibration Fatigue Life from Finite Element Model Calculations

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1995 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: Exposure to random vibration excitation is a test criteria used to screen, compare, and validate components for automotive and aerospace applications.Finite element analysis is sometimes employed to help understand or correct random vibration induced failures.A logical and consistent method for calculating relative fatigue life due to random vibration is needed. The method presented uses the calculated natural frequencies, normalized mode stresses, modal participation factors, and modal damping ratios to synthesize a representative time history which can then be processed through existing damage calculation algorithms such as rainflow counting.

ref.mixed-citation: Crandall, S. and Mark, W.: "Random Vibration in Mechanical Systems": Academic Press, New York and London, 1963
Thompson, W.: "Vibration Theory and Applications": Prentice-Hall, Inc., Englewood Cliffs, NJ 1956

Hieber, G.: "Designing for Dynamics": Hieber Engineering, Watchung, NJ
Newland.D.: "An Introduction to Random Vibrations and Spectral Analysis": Longman, London and New York, 1975
Kohnke, P.: "ANSYS Theoretical Manual for Revision 5.0, Volume IV, Theory": Swanson Analysis, Inc., Houston, PA
Shinkle, G.: "Automotive Component Vibration: A Practical Approach to Accelerated Vibration Durability Testing": SAE paper # 840501
Fuchs, H. and Stephens, R.: "Metal Fatigue in Engineering": John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1980
Otnes, R. and Enochson, L.: "Applied Time Series Analysis": John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1978
Osgood, C.: "Fatigue Design": Pergamon Press, New York, 1982
